Alright, here I go...

So I had an idea (and I'm sure others have had similar thoughts) about the tech tree. Specifically, Parts and Upgrades. I, personally love games that have you upgrade things to make them better.

Here is an example with my system/interpretation of part upgrades...

Each Stage would cost Science and Funds (I am not sure about how much, feel free to put in your 2 cents on it)

There are five stages, ranging one to five, one being the worst and five being the best.

Isp (1 atm) 240 s

Is it worth the development time?

This is just one example, a Mainsail engine might not need a lot of ISP upgrades, but have more Thrust upgrades. Mainly because it is an atmospheric heavy weight booster, not an efficient interplanetary stage.

A battery can have less weight, hold more charge, and cost reduction

General Parts can have weight and cost reductions

So on and so forth...

Note: A few of the calculations are rounded to the nearest tenth and sometimes to the nearest whole number

this is a really good idea. i rather like the idea of having the ability to improve parts over the course of the game. but i think i would model it after nasa's technological readiness level (see link). because thats the process actual space tech goes through from idea to functional component. it would also add the ability to do test flight research on parts (you know jeb wants to).

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technology_readiness_level

instead of having a part instantly unlocked with science, you instead unlock a test prototype. it seems most of the science we have to do thus far has been environmental stuff and not testing any hardware. you could have a model where the environmental science nets you instead of parts, research grants, which can be spent on prototypes (which are crude versions of the final part). testing a prototype raises its trl level which results in a new and improved part (much as how the system you describe works).

to make things interesting, a prototype part would simulate technological bugs, and would there for not be used for a mission critical aspect of space flight. for example, if you test a prototype engine, you may not get reliable operation. it might be prone to overheating, or it might not let you turn it off, or it might cause you to leak fuel. i hate to use the term random failure (for obvious reasons), but thats pretty much it. thing is its still science, so even a failed test will raise the trl. thing to remember here that part use raises its trl. at each level the engine becomes more reliable, more powerful, and the bugs start going away. at arould lvl 8 you have a fully functional and reliable part that you can depend on for mission critical tasks. ultimately if you want to level up a part, you have to use it, its not a thing that should have to be paid for with science or research grants.

I like this idea.

Especially as in a progression up to "Peak Effiency" at which point you would need a new technology.

For simplicity :

- It wouldn't change the model (maybe color marking ?).

- Only the main characteristic(s) would progress proportionally, from 50% -> 75% -> 100%.

- Theoretical maximum would be shown for comparison.

What it would allow :

- Allow parts of various size during early-Career.

- Allow a more progressive evolution of the tech-tree, increasing play time.

- Give occasion to explain the difference between thrust, Isp, and the effect on deltaV

- Give reason to rework rocket design as science march on.

Counter-balance :

- Some engine wouldn't be gimbaled at first.

- Decoupler max strength would change.

Might need to make the progression go relatively quick. I could see folks getting bored doing test launches to level up their new equipment. Face it, they'll be doing enough of that just trying to get various monstrosities into orbit.

I'd level it out at 3 levels (prototype, new, tried'n true). But you could still have steady progression on weight reduction, isp increases, gimbal range and so forth based on certain tech nodes researched.

However, it is possible to make early saved craft unworkable later is the upgrades are completely automatic. If a rocket is designed with a certain twr profile. Later in the game might give it trouble because the late-game twr for those engines might be to high for the ships old design.

So such things will likely need to be frozen when the craft is saved and manually upgradable. Does that make sense?

Perhaps instead of performance changes (which would make exchanging craft designs more difficult), how about each level of "upgrade" reduce the cost once the economy comes in? Basically, the more you understand the parts, the cheaper you could manufacture it.

I think it depend of how you "test" the equipment. If all is needed is a single flight and recovery, there's not that much engine and every body wait a reason to strap Jebediah to a Solid Booster, make VTOL aircraft and else.

I'm more worried about the progression being too fast because of the low numbers of parts.

I'm no fan of automatic upgrade but it would give us a reason to edit/upgrade a sub-assembly / earlier rocket. Though I like my museum of old rocket.

I keep thinking Ratchet and Clank when I read this. Their upgrade system would be awesome implemented into this game.

I do believe that cost should go up with better equipment, not down. That's really the way it is. But as new technologies come around, older ones get cheaper.
